meanings.definition: To soften the colors or outlines of (a painting or drawing) by rubbing or applying a color in a random or haphazard manner.
meanings.sent1: She was scumbling the edges of the painting to make it look softer.
meanings.sent2: Artists often use scumbling to create a more blended effect in their artwork.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous child tried scumbling the lines of his coloring book to make it look like a secret message.
meanings.sent4: Her memories of the past were scumbling the present, creating a dream-like atmosphere.
meanings.sent5: The gentle breeze seemed to be scumbling the colors of the sunset, making it even more beautiful.

meanings.sent1: Learning the scumbling technique can add depth to your artwork.
meanings.sent2: Art students practice the scumbling technique to enhance their paintings.
meanings.sent3: The scumbling technique was like a magic trick that transformed the plain canvas into a masterpiece.
meanings.sent4: His use of the scumbling technique gave his artwork a mysterious aura.
meanings.sent5: The art teacher demonstrated the scumbling technique with finesse, inspiring her students.

meanings.definition: A layer of paint or color applied in a scumble.
meanings.sent1: The artist added a scumbling of blue over the background to create a sense of distance.
meanings.sent2: The final touch of the painting was a delicate scumbling of gold to highlight the details.
meanings.sent3: The cat accidentally left a scumbling of paw prints on the wet paint.
meanings.sent4: The scumbling of red on the flower petals made them appear more vibrant.
meanings.sent5: The subtle scumbling of green added a touch of nature to the artwork.
